Women On Television All Look The Same?



I rather agree with the points that some of the commenters made regarding how nearly everyone on mainstream television (especially females) looks the same.  Hell, even "Ugly Betty" was actually quite pretty.  That said, that is very much mainstream television. There are places like HBO and Showtime that dig deeper and show more diversity.

What else have I been doing...?



The other day we made sour krout, pickled carrots, and quick pickles. The kraut ingredients are so pretty!




Lex, me, and Andrew making pickles.


Here Andrew shows off our picked, purple carrots.  Today I opened them and they fizzed all over the counter.  That's basically a good thing, though, for it shows that the fermentation micro-organisms are at work.




We also attended a fantastic fermentation workshop at the Lama Foundation. The thing was normally $500 (including room and board), but we weren't staying there.  More importantly, we donated large bins of cabbage, cucumbers, and other veggies to the cause so we got to go for free.   The workshop was led by Sandor Katz, a fermentation guru and the guy who ran the workshop thing that Cody attended in Tennessee.

Here is Sandor discussing some smreka (a fermented juniper beverage) that Cody, Andrew, and I had made.  Andrew and I brought it to share with the group.  Actually, Sandor pretty much nailed the reason that I love smreka: it tastes like lighter, non-alcoholic gin.  And gawd knows, I love gin!

 He also has some bad-arse facial hair going on!


The kraut we made:


Andrew and Sandor, making kim chee:

I actually learned a lot about the process, especially about the importance of "bruising" the veggies.  Basically, you stick your hands in this enormous vat of veg (cabbage, carrot, onion, turnip, garlic, ginger, etc.) and squeeze the living crap out of it. It gives the end result a better consistancy, but it's also a great way to relieve oneself of one's aggressions. LOL.



Lama is gorgeous.  Set high upon a mountain it was spiritual center founded with the assistance Ram Dass. In fact, he wrote Be Here Now whilst he was there. Long ago, it was New Buffalo's sister commune, but since we are no longer a commune, I guess we're "just friends" with Lama.  LOL.

The Lama Foundation also makes these fantastic prayer flags.  Andrew and I have a bunch and we sent some to Cody in his massive care-package, too! 

Another funny thing about the weekend was how many people from Lama recognized me from work.  In fact, one guy walked up to me and said, "Oh! You're Maggie's mom, aren't you!?"  I explained that I was actually Maggie's Auntie (after all, she's Greg and Jason's dog), but that just lead into other people coming over and saying, "Hey, I know you from Midtown!"

I just thought this was cute:

So, after the super-fantastic burro race (in which I converted Cody to be another ass-lover, so to speak), we made a decision: we were going to stay on the road one more day.  Thrilled at the prospect, we called Valley View Hot Springs and made a camping reservation.


On the way there, we stopped in Salida, my new favorite town in Colorado.  It is like the Taos of CO, liberal, funky and very, very fun.  We went shopping, found an art show, and basically just chilled for a few hours.  Honestly, I could see ourselves living there at some point if everything worked out.

Cody loves Buffalo and, along with kitsch, Willie, and Walt, finding bison-oriented photographic opportunities was a motif of the trip.


And we found this cool little art shop called Bungled Jungle.






Valley View Hot Springs, though physically gorgeous, turned out to be a very different experience that what we'd expected.  First off, there are myriad rules some of which were very odd and invasive.  For example, technology (cell phones, iPads, etc.) is forbidden everywhere - even in your own campsite, and they even try to tell you how to speak and interact with others. We'd read THIS before we came, but we totally unprepared by the rather oppressive list of additional rules and the manner in which they were carried out.  Consequently, we spent a lot of time getting in trouble. 

As it was raining when we got there, we opted not to set-up our tent immediately and to use our cooler to mark our spot instead.  Yes, there were bear warnings, but it was the middle of the day and the place was crawling with semi-naked people (Valley View is clothing optional), loud families, moving vehicles and other non-bear-friendly environs. Still, when we returned to our site after soaking, we found a passive-aggressive little note from the management threatening to confiscate our cooler should we leave it there after dark. 

The staff, in general, was gloriously unhelpful and Cody pointed out that it seemed as if they'd never been to their own hot springs.  For example, nobody could tell us even an approximate temperature of the pools nor how they were organized.  Worse yet, it was raining and beginning to storm, and, not wishing to be struck be lightening, we inquired as to the safety of the upper pools.
Cody: "So, it looks like we might possibly get lightening, would you say it's safe to use the upper pools."
Staff member:  "I'd never go in the water if there's lightening, but we never give danger advisories or suggest that people not use the pools. They can do what they want."
Me:  "Do you think the storm will actually hit us?"
Staff member: "The lightening might be miles away." 
Cody: "So, do you think it's safe?"
Utter silence.
For the record, we opted to use the pools but leave at the first sign of lightening. Nothing happened.

Later, though, we got into real trouble.  There was a fire ban (no open flame, only smoking in your car, etc.) and, unlike anywhere else on earth, the staff seemed to include propane stoves in that. Other guests (who were all super cool) advised us to just go out the gates and find a spot down the mountain to cook dinner.  As the skies are huge and valley is known as the "UFO Highway" we decided to do just that - and it was glorious.  Dinner was delicious (albeit it very, very spicy), and the stars were amazing. And, yes, we did see a few odd things in the sky.

On our way out a staff member gave us a gate token that we could use on the gate upon our return.  He said absolutely NOTHING about a curfew. However, after re-entering the gate shortly before midnight, we looked back to see a very angry older woman storming towards us clutching a lantern.  Cody was driving (which I thought to be an advantage as he's super cute and charming), so he unrolled the window and spoke to her first. Unfortunately, she beat him to the proverbial punch with one of the most passive-aggressive statement on each, "Can I help you?"

She then proceeded to loudly and vociferously chastise us for coming in after 10:00PM. Cody futilely tried to explain that no one had informed us of the curfew, but his words fell on angry, deaf ears.  "IT'S IN THE RULES, YOU KNOW!!!" she screeched, adding that she ought to make us turn the car around and park outside the gate because we were waking everyone up with our headlights. Cody was extremely sweet and apologetic, but Andrew pointed out that her yelling was probably waking people up as much as our headlights (which, incidentally, were turned off during this conversation).  It should also be noted that turning around would require like a ten-point turn resulting in us shining our headlights into virtually everyone's campsite.  She was not pleased at that, but finally stalked away muttering and swearing. 

We then returned to our campsite, shed our clothes, and took a midnight soak.  If you stay there, the pools are opened all night, but, as in a true summer-camp that is when all the rule-breaking takes place.  There was smoking, there was sex, there were inappropriate conversations with people holding glass bottles, there was food, there was (gasp!) a woman using an iPhone.  We may or may not have broken a few rules ourselves, but that's another story.

It was physically lovely, though, and they had great showers - a plus considering I had to all but go straight to work that next day.

I mentioned the UFO highway thing, here is how serious people are about it. The UFO Watchtower. Much like Roswell, people really capitalize on the UFO phenomenon. Much like Andrew, the woman who owns this place is pretty serious, though.




All in all, it was perhaps the best road trip I've ever been on. We never fought or had moments of not getting along and it was all about love and adventure. Who can beat that?

On day eight we woke early to get to Buena Vista.  Why?   Because it was the day of their big Pack Burro Race, the third leg of the Pack Burro Triple Crown. (And, yes, folks, there really is such a thing.)  Apparently, there are petitions to make pack burro racing the official sport of Colorado. Lest you think that Pack Burro Racing is not really a sport, please know this:  you don't ride the donkey, you run with it - for thirteen miles, in fact.  The burro carries a pack of mining equipment (generally 31 pounds of stuff, but less for the mini donks) and the owner runs along next to it.  It's basically a half-marathon with a running partner who may or may not decide to actually run, occassionally paused to eat sagebrush, and takes numerous dumps whilst moving. These Australian guys cracked me up.  They were searching for the beer tent BEFORE the face.  Do they not realize that they are walking embodiments of the clichéd Australian? Before the race, everyone gathers for weigh-ins and the Blessing of the Burros. (And, yes, that did include liberal use of Holy Water and whole lot of scronking.)  The pastor made a good point, though, mentioning how burros are at least partially responsible for the settling of Colorado and its fame in mining. The mini donks (see below) were Cody's favorites, and the Mammoths were Andrew's.  I made a burro convert out of Cody and we all decided that someday we'll become donkey breeders.  Of course, I had to point out to Cody that that is the ONLY way he'll ever be a breeder. LOL. For some reason there were also an abundance of wiener dogs at the race.  Do donkeys and wiener dogs go together, somehow? Apparently, the burros tend to make friends with one another and race in packs - or herds, I guess.  That can be an advantage or a disadvantage depending upon one's strategy to win. One of my faves, a Poitou. And they're off!  The guy in the corner of the shot actually had the starter gun. LOL. And you can see, some run and some don't. And this is what they leave behind. The race takes a couple of hours, so we went to breakfast whilst the actual athletes (both animal and human) ran a grueling thirteen-mile course through the mountains. It was a hot day, too. However, we were there for the finish. And we all had to pose with the winner: This was the Second Place Winner, a Jenny named Moxie.  Jennies (females) are not than common in burro racing, but the kid (he's like in high school) who owns her is really into it. Hey, I'm all for Girl Power! (Or Jenny Power?)

The next day dawned with most of us feeling tired and a little worn-out.  Still, we had Walt and Willie and one another, and all was beautiful.  We headed for Buena Vista, Colorado (which, oddly the locals pronounce as "Bewna Vista" and the Collegiate Peaks area.  I don't have the actual shot, but, predictably, we had to photograph Cody with Mount Yale.


Part of my personal malaise was aesthetics, for I was REALLY unimpressed by our campsite. It was truly one of the ugliest places I've ever camped, the scrubby bush and constant layer of litter rather reminding me of adolescent camping trips in CA. Cody and Andrew, however, loved it. In the end, though, it proved to be lots of fun.  Cody and I played Scrabble whilst Andrew cooked and then we all went to Cottonwood Hot Springs.




This "unusual art formation" rather made us giggle.  Cody and I kept looking up at the cliff above our campsite and trying to ascertain as to what the colorful splotch was about halfway up the mountain.  It appeared to be at the entrance to a cave, but when I finally remembered to use my zoom lens, I discovered something very amusing and stonerish... a happy mushroom!  I've no idea who painted it, but it must have been quite a hike (not to mention a precarious balance) just to paint the damn thing.  I'm assuming actual mushrooms were involved.


Cody chills in the campsite before we headed off to town.




Town was fun.  Buena Vista was having "Gold Rush Days" (the coolest part of which will be in tomorrow's post), but suffice it to say that there was a little fair with with booths and art and all that fun stuff.  And can anyone guess what the highlight was?  Again, you'll find out tomorrow, but I'll give you a couple of hints:  First off, it's nominated to be the new State Sport of Colorado. Second, it involves my favorite animal.


Physical irony: a horse made of horse shoes.


Cody tried on hats.

So, Walt in hand and Willie singing in our ears, we left Utah via Highway 70 and some of the most frighteningly desolate country on earth.  Soon, however, we left that for the relative safety of the mountains of Colorado.


After the heat of Utah and the desolation of the highway, we needed to seek solace in water. Luckily, we were armed with our trusty handbooks detailing hot springs and camping spots. Our goal was to find either to hit Glenwood Springs or, better yet, find something unmaintained. Though we found one excellent possibility of the latter in our handbook, we unfortunately discovered that all (and I do mean literally all) of the available campsites within about a seven mile radius of the place were completely full.

So we moved on... and on and on and on. Virtually everything was full. We passed all the way through Glenwood, CO, saw the Glenwood Hot Springs and decided to pass on that, too. It just seemed to big and family-oriented for our needs. In fact, it was more like a water park that a traditional hot spring.

However, on our way to a new crop of camp grounds on the other side of the town, we saw a group of cars parked on a small turn-off on the side of the road. "Look!" cried Andrew, a woman in a bathing suit. And, as anyone who knows about unmaintained hot springs understands, that is a good sign. And, sure enough, there was a wild hot spring down there. So we traveled on, found a camping spot in a camp ground hosted by a very unamused couple from Yuma, Arizona, and the headed back to the springs.

The springs, called Penny Hot Springs, were utterly fantastic: super hot water flowed into two decent-sized pools next to the Crystal River.  There were only a few people there, but all were totally cool, including this wild girl named Joy who was the closest thing we'd found to Cody's sought-after gypsy.  We soaked from just before sunset until well after the dark, and the hot water was phenomenal.  But that best part of all? We saw another of those orb/fairy things!!! Seriously, we looked up at the road by the rock below and saw a very bright, white-blue light flashing along. At first Cody and I thought it was a bicyclist - until the light took off down the hill and followed along above the river.  It was Cody's first experience with that and it was super cool.
This is were we saw if, but it was at night.


After soaking we returned to the campsite where we felt nearly harassed by the hosts who toodled around in a little golf-cart. We were the youngest people in the campground by a good couple of decades at least, and by far the most... erm... liberal. Still, it was fun.

The next day we headed over Independence Pass. We briefly thought about stopping in Aspen, but, after having seeing the over-crowded, over-priced, bougie yuppiness of the place, we gave it a miss. Lloyd of Dumb and Dumber was wrong when he said, "Someplace warm. A place where the beer flows like wine. Where beautiful women instinctively flock like the salmon of Capistrano. I'm talking about a little place called Aspen." Rather, it was chock full of expensively dressed people riding bikes, shopping at Dior, and waiting to be served in over-priced cafes.

Independence Pass, though, was quite beautiful.






We stopped at the Continental Divide. I'll admit it, I'm still weirded out by how far west the Continental Divide actually is. It's west of us in New Mexico, even. For some reason I always thought of it more in the middle of the country.


This water seemed to stay on top, flowing neither to the Pacific nor the Atlantic.



By this time we'd been in the car forever (not to mention on a very high pass with a VERY narrow road), so we were all getting "punchy." Here we have Cody's Sound of Music impression.


And then Andrew and Cody decided to celebrate the moment through dance. I won't say whether or not I joined in, but you'll never know because I was holding the camera.


We moved on that night to yet another campsite where we were tremendouly unpopular.  This time, however, it was full of Mormon families who were not amused by our gin and our Jager and... erm.. all the other stuff.  Other than the African-American family (also rather ostracized) is the spot next to ours, no one even spoke to us - even when we said "hi" first.  At one point a little kid on a bike saw me coming and turned around and fled.  It was actually quite amusing.

Day Four was also spent in Moab, exploring the (tiny) town and surrounding area. Many of 'yall will be relieved to note that I actually took very few pictures that day, so you're screens are safe. Anyway, had breakfast and wandered around town taking in the tiny tourist boutiques and thrift stores.  In fact, the thrift stores was perhaps the most fun, for we found somethings we actually needed, plus a "necessary" items like a whiffleball bat and a Maraiah Carey tape. LOL. We also managed to find Cody some retro sunglasses and fake pearls.  The glasses are - no sh*t - vintage New Kids on the Block! I just found some on eBay for like $23, but we paid one whole dollar.  Look at us go! But the main focus of our day was Dead Horse Point State Park... For those who are not familiar with Dead Horse Point, it was where the final scene in the movie, Thelma and Louise was filmed.  For those not familiar with the movie, Thelma and Louise, y'all are totally missing out, for it's an incredible story about strong, wild women who refuse to take any sort of abuse. Plus, it features Susan Sarandon and a scene in which Geena Davis robs a bank. As it is one of Cody's favorite movies, too, he pretty much insisted on our going here so that he could perform his prayer to "Saint Thelma" and "Saint Louise" patron saints of female bank robbers, abused women, and strong female leads! Anyway, Dead Horse Point looks a lot like the Grand Canyon, does it not? This is one of my favorite shots of "Adventurer Andrew." Andrew and I - as usual trying NOT to stare directly into the sun. Prom pose! I am very fond of THIS Casper David Freidrich painting and I was kind of going for the Western version of it in this shot. After Dead Horse Point, we returned to the motel and took a nap - and before you start muttering about how lame that sounds, keep in mind that it was over 101 degrees Fahrenheit.  In hot lands, the siesta becomes as necessary as water - trust me on this.  Upon waking we explored the town a bit more, poking through geology shops, purchasing fossils, perusing used book stores, and looking at all the clothes I neither needed nor had room for in the car.  It was fun, but we had little time as (thank you, Utah's strange alcohol laws) our main destination closed at 7:00PM.  Yes, in defiance of all that Utah stands for, we proceeded to visit every winery, brewery, and distillery we could find.  That night it was the Castle Creek Winery, located in this beautiful valley nestled by the Colorado River.  We went wine tasting, purchased several bottles, and then proceeded to drink most all of it in Arches National Park. That night was truly magical.  Sadly - or perhaps for the best - I forgot my camera, but our return to Arches resulted in scenery even more beautiful than the first time.  Again, it was nearly close to sunset when we started hiking, but the walk to Landscape Arch and Double Arch proved gorgeous.  Oddly, as with nearly everywhere else we visited in southern Utah, we were nearly the only Americans present.  Most everyone else was European - mostly from Germany, Austria, Belgium, Norway, Finland, Sweden, Denmark or elsewhere in northern Europe. My guess is that people from that area come to the American West because A) the landscape is like no where else they're used to and B) they come from a fairly "outdoorsy" culture so the hiking, camping, etc. is pretty natural. Also, it was great because northern European women are awesome and wear things like sun-dresses and hiking shoes. Why am I impressed with this? Because I was, too, and it was great not to be the only fool wearing a sun-dress to National Park. (It was the tie-dyed thingie, ftr.) Once the sun finally set, we made our way to an empty area near a campground, drank wine, and watched the stars.
